How Islamology stepped out of French academia's shadows after the 2015 jihadist attacks
subhead: Once a jewel of French research, Islamology began to decline in the 1980s, but the 2015 attacks forced authorities to refocus their efforts in this field of knowledge. Although the discipline has since experienced something of a revival, its recovery remains fragile, both as an academic subject and a highly political issue.

title: Trump officials host crucial Ukraine peace talks in Florida
Pope Leo XIV urges Lebanese to resist exodus and choose reconciliation
The last-minute fight to save Gaza's ancient archaeological treasures
subhead: Amid the vast destruction of the war, a small group of determined individuals fought to save Gaza's archaeological heritage. On September 10, they secured a few hours' reprieve from the Israeli army before a storage depot filled with artifacts was bombed to perform a delicate evacuation – the result of intense, high-level negotiations.

title: Angoulême seeks an alternative to its ailing comics festival
subhead: The central French town has launched an alternative project of cultural offerings, aiming to calm the discontent of local shopkeepers and service providers, who are seeing substantial economic returns evaporate.

title: Kikuo Ibe's quest to build the unbreakable watch
subhead: Forty-two years after inventing the first indestructible watch, the Casio G-Shock, the Japanese engineer continues to inspire. As part of a European tour, he stopped in France to meet his fans.

title: 'Dédé la Sardine' and Russian oil: Inside the affair that has haunted Total for 15 years
subhead: Seven people have been ordered to stand trial for their involvement in an arbitration process that was allegedly manipulated in order to extract the equivalent of €16 billion from French oil company Total. Their trial begins on Monday.

title: Paris restaurants with a New York attitude
The art of being Oscar Wilde's grandson
Gay Talese, the last titan of the American press
subhead: He was a pioneer of New Journalism, a movement that transformed American journalism with a literary writing style. At 93, the author of the landmark 1966 profile 'Frank Sinatra Has a Cold,' finds his daily life increasingly constrained by old age.

title: Andriy Yermak's resignation shocks Europe, but suits the US
subhead: With Volodymyr Zelensky's top aide stepping down, the EU loses a key interlocutor in Kyiv at a pivotal moment in peace talks. The Trump administration, by contrast, seems ready to leverage the crisis to push its own priorities.
byline: By Philippe Ricard, Piotr Smolar (Washington (United States) correspondent) and Philippe Jacqué (Brussels, Europe bureau)

title: Filippo Sorcinelli, the man who dresses the pope
subhead: The Italian designer is one of the Vatican's preferred tailors. At 50, he has dressed the last three popes, including Leo XIV. Catholic and gay, he has patiently – and indulgently – observed the slow evolution of the Church.
byline: By Pierre Terraz (Santarcangelo di Romagna (Italy), special correspondent)
